passage_text: Underemployment refers to an employment situation that is insufficient in some important way for the worker, relative to a standard. Examples include holding a part-time job despite desiring full-time work, and overqualification, where the employee has education, experience, or skills beyond the requirements of the job. 1  Overqualification  or overeducation, or the employment of workers with high education, skill levels, or experience in jobs that do not require such abilities. 2  For example, a trained medical doctor who works as a taxi driver would experience this type of underemployment.

Underemployment is a social problem that affects job growth, poverty levels, business growth, career growth, and the emotional health of underemployed workers. Underemployment is a vicious cycle in which each effect is linked to the next. For instance, underemployed workers generally have less disposable income. Therefore, workers have a tendency to spend less, which impacts business growth, poverty levels, and ultimately the emotional health of underemployed workers
